title: 107_hr5176
content: The "Veterans' Heritage Firearms Act of 2002" allows veterans an amnesty period to register qualifying firearms. During the amnesty period, veterans or their family members can register qualifying firearms acquired before October 31, 1968, while the veteran was stationed outside the continental United States. During the amnesty period, veterans or their family members can register qualifying firearms acquired before October 31, 1968, while the veteran was stationed outside the continental United States. In the absence of clear evidence to the contrary, the Secretary must accept any submitted evidence to establish firearm requirements and hold a hearing if registration is denied. Individuals registering firearms under subsection (a) are granted limited immunity from criminal liability under title 18. Individuals who register a firearm under subsection (a) are granted immunity from criminal liability under chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, for any violations related to ownership, possession, transportation, importation, or alteration of the firearm that occurred before or concurrent with the registration. Any individual who registers a firearm under subsection (a) is exempt from criminal liability under the Internal Revenue Code for violations related to the firearm that occurred before or at the time of registration. Transfer tax liability remains unaffected. Registered firearms are not subject to seizure or forfeiture for violations under the Internal Revenue Code or title 18, United States Code. Definitions for this section include the term "amnesty period" as a 90-day period after the enactment of the Act. The term "firearm" excludes certain devices and parts intended for conversion. The term "applicable veteran" refers to a veteran described in subsection (b)(1)(B), while "veteran" is defined as per section 101(2) of title 38, United States Code. The term "family" includes grandparents, lineal descendants, and spouses of descendants, with legal separations still considered spouses. Individuals related by half blood or legal adoption are treated as if they were related by full blood. Legal adoption is considered the same as being related by full blood. The term "continental United States" excludes Alaska and Hawaii. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. TRANSFER OF MACHINEGUNS TO MUSEUMS: Amends Section 922(o)(2) of title 18, United States Code to allow transfer, possession, or transfer by museums incorporated as not-for-profit corporations under State law.
